revised_title: Inferences from Bright Lines in Nebula Spectra
tldr: William Huggins examines the spectra of irresolvable nebulae and finds that the bright lines present do not support Mr. Stone's hypothesis that these celestial bodies have a constitution different from stars and mainly consist of glowing gas. Huggins also critiques the theory itself, stating that it is open to objections and does not align with the results of observation.
